notesStmt.note: The first leaf bears royal arms on verso.
C2r line 30 begins "Like glass we clearness mixt". Variant: line begins "And glass-like clearness mixt".
Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.p: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE

div.p: Atraea Redux. A POEM On the Happy Retoration & Return Of His Sacred Majety Charles the Second. By JOHN DRIDEN.
div.q: Jam Redit & Virgo, Redeunt Saturnia Regna.
div.p: LONDON, Printed by J. M. for Henry Herringman, and are to be old at his Shop, at the Blew-Anchor, in the lower Walk of the New-Exchange, 1660.

div.head: Atraea Redux. A POEM On the Happy Retoration and Return of His Sacred MAJESTY Charles the Second.

lg.l: NOw with a general Peace the World was blet,
While Ours, a World divided from the ret,
A dreadful Quiet felt, and worer farre
Then Armes, a ullen Intervall of Warre:
Thus when black Clouds draw down the lab'ring Skies,
Ere yet abroad the winged Thunder flyes
An horrid Stillnes firt invades the ear,
And in that ilence Wee the Tempet fear.
Th' Ambitious Swede like retles Billowes tot,
On this hand gaining what on that he lot,
Though in his life he Blood and Ruine breath'd
To his now guideles Kingdome Peace bequeath'd.
And Heaven that eem'd regardles of our Fate,
For France and Spain did Miracles create,
Such mortal Quarrels to compoe in Peace
As Nature bred and Int'ret did encreae.
We igh'd to hear the fair Iberian Bride
Mut grow a Lilie to the Lilies ide,
While Our cros Stars deny'd us Charles his Bed
Whom Our firt Flames and Virgin Love did wed.
For his long abence Church and State did groan;
Madnes the Pulpit, Faction eiz'd the Throne:
Experienc'd Age in deep depair was lot
To ee the Rebel thrive, the Loyal crot:
Youth that with Joys had unacquainted been
Envy'd gray hairs that once good days had een:
We thought our Sires, not with their own content,
Had ere we came to age our Portion pent.
Nor could our Nobles hope their bold Attempt
Who ruin'd Crowns would Coronets exempt:
For when by their deigning Leaders taught
To trike at Pow'r which for themelves they ought,
The Vulgar gull'd into Rebellion, arm'd,
Their blood to action by the Prize was warm'd.
The Sacred Purple then and Scarlet Gown
Like anguine Dye to Elephants was hown.
Thus when the bold Typhoeus cal'd the Sky,
And forc'd great Jove from his own Heaven to fly,
(What King, what Crown from Treaons reach is free,
If Jove and Heaven can violated be?)
The leer Gods that har'd his prop'rous State
All uffer'd in the Exil'd Thund'rers Fate.
The Rabble now uch Freedom did enjoy,
As Winds at Sea that ue it to detroy:
Blind as the Cyclops, and as wild as he,
They own'd a lawles alvage Libertie,
Like that our painted Ancetours o priz'd
Ere Empires Arts their Breats had Civiliz'd.
How Great were then Our Charles his Woes, who thus
Was forc'd to uffer for Himelf and us!
He tos'd by Fate, and hurried up and down,
Heir to his Fathers Sorrows, with his Crown,
Could tat no weets of youths deired Age,
But found his life too true a Pilgrimage.
Unconquer'd yet in that forlorne Etate
His Manly Courage overcame his Fate.
His wounds he took like Romans on his bret,
Which by his Vertue were with Lawrells dret.
As Souls reach Heav'n while yet in Bodies pent,
So did he live above his Banihment.
That Sun which we beheld with cous'ned eyes
Within the water, mov'd along the skies.
How eaie 'tis when Detiny proves kind
With full pread Sails to run before the wind,
But thoe that 'gaint tiff gales laveering go
Mut be at once reolv'd and skilfull too.
He would not like oft Otho hope prevent
But tay'd and uffer'd Fortune to repent.
Thee Vertues Galba in a tranger ought;
And Pio to Adopted Empire brought.
How hall I then my doubtful thoughts expres
That mut his uff'rings both regret and bles!
For when his early Valour Heav'n had crot,
And all at Worc'ter but the honour lot,
Forc'd into exile from his rightful Throne
He made all Countries where he came his own.
And viewing Monarchs ecret Arts of way
A Royal Factor for their Kingdomes lay.
Thus banih'd David pent abroad his time.
When to be Gods Anointed was his Crime
And when retor'd made his proud Neighbours rue
Thoe choie Remarques he from his Travels drew,
Nor is he onely by afflictions hown
To conquer others Realms but rule his own:
Recov'ring hardly what he lot before
His right indears it much, his purchae more.
Inur'd to uffer ere he came to raigne
No rah procedure will his actions tain.
To bus'nes ripened by digetive thought
His future rule is into Method brought:
As they who firt Proportion undertand
With eaie Practice reach a Maters hand.
Well might the Ancient Poets then confer
On Night the honour'd name of Couneller,
Since truck with rayes of prop'rous fortune blind
We light alone in dark afflictions find.
In uch adverities to Scepters train'd
The name of Great his famous Grandire gain'd:
Who yet a King alone in Name and Right,
With hunger, cold and angry Jove did fight;
Shock'd by a Covenanting Leagues vat Pow'rs
As holy and as Catholique as ours:
Till Fortunes fruitles pight had made it known
Her blowes not hook but riveted his Throne.
Some lazy Ages lot in leep and eae
No action leave to buie Chronicles;
Such whoe upine felicity but makes
In tory Chames, in Epoche's mitakes;
O're whom Time gently hakes his wings of Down
Till with his ilent ickle they are mown:
Such is not Charles his too too active age,
Which govern'd by the wild ditemper'd rage
Of ome black Star infecting all the Skies,
Made him at his own cot like Adam wie.
Tremble ye Nations who ecure before
Laught at thoe Armes that 'gaint our elves we bore;
Rous'd by the lah of his own tubborn tail
Our Lyon now will forraign Foes aail.
With Alga who the acred altar trowes?
To all the Sea-Gods Charles an Offring owes:
A Bull to thee Portunus hall be lain
A Lamb to you the Tempets of the Main:
For thoe loud tormes that did againt him rore
Have cat his hipwrack'd Veel on the hore.
Yet as wie Artits mix their colours o
That by degrees they from each other go,
Black teals unheeded from the neighb'ring white
Without offending the well cous'ned ight:
So on us tole our bleed change; while we
Th' effect did feel but carce the manner ee.
Frots that contrain the ground, and birth deny
To flow'rs, that in its womb expecting lye,
Do eldom their uurping Pow'r withdraw,
But raging floods purue their haty thaw:
Our thaw was mild, the cold not chas'd away
But lot in kindly heat of lengthned day.
Heav'n would no bargain for its blesings drive
But what we could not pay for, freely give.
The Prince of Peace would like himelf confer
A gift unhop'd without the price of war.
Yet as he knew his blesings worth, took care
That we hould know it by repeated pray'r;
Which torm'd the skies and ravih'd Charles from thence
As Heav'n it elf is took by violence.
Booth's forward Valour only erv'd to how
He durt that duty pay we all did owe:
Th' Attempt was fair; but Heav'ns prefixed hour
Not come; o like the watchful travellour
That by the Moons mitaken light did rie,
Lay down again, and clos'd his weary eyes.
'Twas MONCK whom Providence deign'd to looe
Thoe real bonds fale freedom did impoe.
The bleed Saints that watch'd this turning Scene
Did from their Stars with joyful wonder leane,
To ee mall clues draw vatet weights along,
Not in their bulk but in their order trong.
Thus Pencils can by one light touch retore
Smiles to that changed face that wept before.
With eae uch fond Chymaera's we purue
As fancy frames for fancy to ubdue,
But when our elves to action we betake
It huns the Mint like gold that Chymits make:
How hard was then his task, at once to be
What in the body natural we ee
Mans Architect ditinctly did ordain
The charge of Mucles, Nerves, and of the Brain;
Through viewles Conduits Spirits to dipene,
The Springs of Motion from the Seat of Sene.
'Twas not the haty product of a day,
But the well ripened fruit of wie delay.
He like a patient Angler, er'e he trooke
Would let them play a while upon the hook.
Our healthful food the Stomach labours thus
At firt embracing what it trait doth cruh.
Wie Leeches will not vain Receipts obtrude,
While growing pains pronounce the humours crude;
Deaf to complaints they wait upon the ill
Till ome afe Criis authorie their skill.
Nor could his Acts too cloe a vizard wear
To cape their eyes whom guilt had taught to fear,
And guard with caution that polluted net
Whence Legion twice before was dipoet.
Once acred houe which when they enter'd in
They thought the place could anctifie a in;
Like thoe that vainly hop'd kind Heav'n would wink
While to exces on Martyrs tombs they drink.
And as devouter Turks firt warn their ouls
To part, before they tat forbidden bowls,
So thee when their black crimes they went about
Firt timely charm'd their ueles concience out.
Religions name againt it elf was made;
The hadow erv'd the ubtance to invade:
Like Zealous Misions they did care pretend
Of ouls in hew, but made the Gold their end.
Th' incened Powr's beheld with corn from high
An Heaven o far ditant from the sky,
Which durt with hores hoofs that beat the ground
And Martial bras bely the thunders ound.
'Twas hence at length jut Vengeance thought it fit
To peed their ruine by their impious wit.
Thus Sforza curs'd with a too fertile brain
Lot by his wiles the Pow'r his wit did gain.
Henceforth their Fogue mut pend at leer rate
Then in its flames to wrap a Nations Fate.
Suffer'd to live, they are like Helots et
A vertuous hame within us to beget.
For by example mot we inn'd before,
And glas-like clearnes mixt with frailty bore.
But ince reform'd by what we did amis,
We by our uff'rings learn to prize our blis.
Like early Lovers whoe unpractis'd hearts
Were long the May-game of malicious arts,
When once they find their Jealouies were vain
With double heat renew their fires again.
'Twas this produc'd the joy that hurried o're
Such warmes of Englih to the Neighb'ring hore,
To fetch that prize, by which Batavia made
So rich amends for our impoverih'd Trade.
Oh had you een from Schevelines barren hore
(Crowded with troops, and barren now no more,)
Afflicted Holland to his farewell bring
True Sorrow, Holland to regret a King;
While waiting him his Royal Fleet did ride
And willing winds to their low'rd ayles deny'd.
The wavering Streamers, Flags, and Standart out
The merry Seamens rude but chearful hout,
And lat the Cannons voice that hook the skies
And, as it fares in udden Extaies
At once bereft us both of ears and eyes.
The Naeby now no longer Englands hame
But better to be lot in Charles his name
(Like ome unequal Bride in nobler heets)
Receives her Lord: the joyful London meets
The Princely York, himelf alone a freight;
The Swift-ure groans beneath Great Gloc'ters weight.
Secure as when the Halcyon breeds, with thee
He that was born to drown might cros the Seas.
Heav'n could not own a Providence and take
The wealth three Nations ventur'd at a take.
The ame indulgence Charles his Voyage bles'd
Which in his right had Miracles confes'd.
The winds that never Moderation knew
Afraid to blow too much, too faintly blew;
Or out of breath with joy could not enlarge
Their traightned lungs, or concious of their Charge.
The Britih Amphitryte mooth and clear
In richer Azure never did appear;
Proud her returning Prince to entertain
With the ubmitted Faces of the Main.
ANd welcome now (Great Monarch) to your own;
Behold th' approaching cliffes of Albion;
It is no longer Motion cheats your view,
As you meet it, the Land approacheth you.
The Land returns, and in the white it wears
The marks of penitence and orrow bears.
But you, whoe goodnes your dicent doth how,
Your Heav'nly Parentage and earthly too;
By that ame mildnes which your Fathers Crown
Before did ravih, hall ecure your own.
Not ty'd to rules of Policy, you find
Revenge les weet then a forgiving mind.
Thus when th' Almighty would to Moes give
A ight of all he could behold and live;
A voice before his entry did proclaim
Long-Suff'ring, Goodnes, Mercy in his Name.
Your Pow'r to Jutice doth ubmit your Caue,
Your Goodnes only is above the Laws;
Whoe rigid letter while pronounc'd by you
Is ofter made. So winds that tempets brew
When through Arabian Groves they take their flight
Made wanton with rich Odours, loe their pight.
And as thoe Lees that trouble it, refine
The agitated Soul of Generous Wine,
So tears of joy for your returning pilt,
Work out and expiate our former guilt.
Methinks I ee thoe Crowds on Dovers Strand
Who in their hat to welcome you to Land
Choak'd up the Beach with their till growing tore,
And made a wilder Torrent on the hore.
While purr'd with eager thoughts of pat delight
Thoe who had een you, court a econd ight;
Preventing till your teps, and making hat
To meet you often where o e're you pat.
How hall I peak of that triumphant Day
When you renew'd the expiring Pomp of May!
(A Month that owns an Intret in your Name:
You and the Flow'rs are its peculiar Claim.)
That Star that at your Birth hone out o bright
It tain'd the duller Suns Meridian light,
Did once again its potent Fires renew
Guiding our eyes to find and worhip you.
And now times whiter Series is begun
Which in oft Centuries hall moothly run;
Thoe Clouds that overcat your Morne hall fly
Dipell'd to farthet corners of the sky.
Our Nation with united Int'ret blet
Not now content to poize, hall way the ret.
Abroad your Empire hall no Limits know,
But like the Sea in boundles Circles flow.
Your much lov'd Fleet hall with a wide Command
Beiege the petty Monarchs of the Land:
And as Old Time his Off-pring wallow'd down
Our Ocean in its depths all Seas hall drown.
Their wealthy Trade from Pyrates Rapine free
Our Merchants hall no more Advent'rers be:
Nor in the farthet Eat thoe Dangers fear
Which humble Holland mut diemble here.
Spain to your Gift alone her Indies owes;
For what the Pow'rful takes not he betowes.
And France that did an Exiles preence fear
May jutly apprehend you till too near.
At home the hateful names of Parties ceae
And factious Souls are weary'd into peace.
The dicontented now are only they
Whoe Crimes before did your Jut Caue betray:
Of thoe your Edicts ome reclaim from ins,
But mot your Life and Blet Example wins.
Oh happy Prince whom Heav'n hath taught the way
By paying Vowes, to have more Vowes to pay!
Oh Happy Age! Oh times like thoe alone
By Fate reerv'd for Great Augutus Throne!
When the joint growth of Armes and Arts forehew
The World a Monarch, and that Monarch You.
